# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import missingno as msno
from wordcloud import WordCloud
import warnings

warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category = FutureWarning)

sns.set(style="darkgrid")

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

source.3622fbee:
fig = make_subplots(
    rows=3, cols=2,
    subplot_titles=("Ship Mode", "Segment", "Region", "Category", "Sub-Category",  "State"))

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['Ship Mode']), row=1, col=1)

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['Segment']), row=1, col=2)

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['Region']), row=2, col=1)

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['Category']), row=2, col=2)

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['Sub-Category']), row=3, col=1)

fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = store_data['State']), row=3, col=2)


fig.update_layout(height=800, width=800,
                  template='plotly_dark',
                  title_text="Value Counts from Each Feature")

fig.show()
source.f6c1d96c: city_wise = store_data[["City", "Sales", 'Profit']].groupby(['City'], as_index=False).sum().sort_values(by=['Sales', 'Profit'], ascending=False) fig = px.bar(data_frame = city_wise.head(20), x = "City", y = "Sales", color="City", hover_data=['Sales', 'Profit'], template='plotly_dark', title = "Top 20 cities where most products are sold") fig.show()
source.b0c5c008: city_wise = store_data[["City", "Sales", 'Profit']].groupby(['City'], as_index=False).sum().sort_values(by=['Sales', 'Profit'], ascending=False) fig = px.bar(data_frame = city_wise.tail(20), x = "City", y = "Sales", color="City", hover_data=['Sales', 'Profit'], template='plotly_dark', title = "Buttom 20 cities where less products are sold") fig.show()
source.a28eb6db:
def plot_word_cloud(col_name):    
    text = ' '.join(store_data[col_name].str.lower())

    wordcloud = WordCloud(width = 2000, height = 900, 
                          background_color ='black',
                          collocations=False,
                          max_words=5000,
                          min_font_size = 15).generate(text)

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8), facecolor = 'k', edgecolor = 'k' )
    plt.imshow(wordcloud)
    plt.axis("off")
    plt.tight_layout(pad = 0) 
    plt.show()

source.29844749:
Conclusion


* Major shipping mode is Standard Class * Tables sub-category generates the lowest profit * Copiers sub-category generates the highest profit * Maximum sales are from Binders, Paper, Furnishings, Phones, Storage, Art, Accessories Minimum sales are from Copies, Machines,and Suppliers. * **Top 5 sub-categories which generates more profit** * Copiers * Phones * Accessories * Paper * Binders * **Top 5 cities which has highest number of buyers** * New York City * Los Angeles * Seattle * San Francisco * Philadelphia * **Buttom 5 cities cities has less numbers of buyers** * Ormond Beach * Pensacola * Jupiter * Elyria * Abilene
